thread.title: Kenya: Road Safety Plan Welcome

title: Kenya: Road Safety Plan Welcome
text:
Rwanda: Kigala's Smart Bus Initiative Looks to Persuade 182,000 Car Drivers Off the Road - Phase Two Will Put Timetable in Hands of Users editorial 
The proposal to check the vision of candidates seeking to join driving schools is welcome as it is an acknowledgement that poor eyesight is one of the human factors that lead to road crashes, especially in bad weather and at night. 
In fact, Tanzania already makes it mandatory for drivers to have their eyes tested. 
Road safety calls for a holistic approach and fixing the roads and the cars is just part of the challenge. Reducing the probability of human error or weakness, such as poor vision, will go a long way in reducing the number of crashes. 
However, welcome as the proposal by the National Transport and Safety Authority would be, such a measure would be rendered pointless unless traffic police officers, hospitals, driving schools, and regulators enforce it to ensure that candidates actually undergo the tests and do not get certified without being examined. 
The proposal that the number of hours that learners spend on the theory part be increased is also a step in the right direction. 
Often, crashes are caused by poor understanding of the Highway Code. Increasing the hours spent learning traffic rules will no doubt go a long way in improving safety on Kenyan roads. Kenya
